docs.lead_paragraph: Cowboys (7-6) at Buccaneers (4-9) Saturday, 8:20 p.m. Line: Cowboys by 7 Two of the league's most idiosyncratic late-game tacticians face off in a game destined to turn into toddler chess (''my horsy got magic powers and blow'd up all your pointy guys'') in the final minutes. Jason Garrett's late-game over-complications have become the stuff of legend, but let's listen in on Raheem Morris's clock-management dissertation after the Buccaneers' loss to the Titans a few weeks ago: ''We spike the ball after every first down you get. You pick up a first down, you have to go spike it, you have no timeouts left. Every first down after that point has got to be a spiked ball.'' Somewhere, Herm Edwards, and only Herm Edwards, is nodding in approval. Clock-management issues have become increasingly moot during the Buccaneers' seven-game losing streak as 37-9 and 41-14 losses have piled up. Josh Freeman has been battling both inconsistency and shoulder and finger injuries, and the Buccaneers' defense often caves in at the red zone, having allowed 14 touchdowns in their opponents' last 17 trips inside the 20. With Freeman spraying passes and the Bucs waving opponents into the end zone like parking lot attendants, Garrett can enjoy a consequence-free last-second timeout spree if he chooses. Pick: Cowboys

docs.lead_paragraph: The 112th Congress lurched toward the end of its tumultuous first session Friday as the House passed a $1 trillion spending bill and sent it to the Senate for approval.

headline.seo: Senate Agrees to Short-Term Extension of Payroll Tax Cut
headline.main: Senate Leaders Agree on 2-Month Extension of Payroll Tax Cut
headline.print_headline: Senate in Deal To Extend Cuts In Payroll Tax

docs.abstract: Senate leaders say they have reached deal to extend payroll tax cut for two months, falling far short of yearlong extension they were seeking; deal will speed decision process for construction of Keystone XL pipeline, provision necessary to win over Republicans who opposed tax break; rank-and-file members of House say they are opposed to short-term extension, and approval in that chamber, even with pipeline provision, is uncertain; separately, House passes $1 trillion spending bill that will keep government funded through September 2012.
docs.snippet: The 112th Congress lurched toward the end of its tumultuous first session Friday as the House passed a $1 trillion spending bill and sent it to the Senate for approval.

byline.original: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: Daniel Ruettinger may have turned his tale as one of the sports world's ultimate underdogs into a highly profitable motivational speaking career and the movie ''Rudy.'' But his reputation wasn't enough to ward off fraud charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The agency on Friday sued Mr. Ruettinger and 12 others in federal district court in Las Vegas, charging them with running a pump-and-dump investment scheme in 2008 that reaped more than $11 million in illicit gains.

headline.main: Real-Life 'Rudy' Charged With Stock Fraud Scheme

docs.abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission sues Daniel Ruettinger, the inspiration for the movie Rudy, on fraud charges; SEC says he and 12 others ran a pump-and-dump investment scheme in 2008 that reaped more than $11 million in illicit gains. (M)h
